section.name: Maven Eve Plugin
section.p: Currently the primary function of the plugin is to generates Eve class files for OpenLDAP schemas. These class files contain hard coded schema objects representing those found in the OpenLDAP files. Why bother you may ask? There are a few reasons for this:

ul.li: Compiled hard coded files load into the server really fast in theory.
Published schemas never really change so why do they need to be in a human readable form.
Eventually, schema changes made through LDAP will be preserved through restarts.
Extra code generation phase is not that hard with a plugin tool.
Schema verification can occur before deploying schemas into the server.
This was really easy for now but if people don't like it we can change it.

goal.name: eve:generate
goal.description: Generates class files for OpenLDAP schemas.

goal.name: eve:init
goal.description: Finds the required parameters needed for the goals of the plugin.

goal.name: eve:prepare-filesystem
goal.description: Creates source output directories used to deposite schema files that are generated.

goal.name: eve:schema
goal.description: Top level schema generating function that uses other goals to coordinate generation.

subsection.p: Take a look at how we integrate this into the Eve build here.

section.name: How to Integrate
section.p: Ok so you want to use the plugin to generate classes for your own schema. Here's a step wise process you can follow to do that using maven:

ol.li: Place your schema files (i.e. foo.schema) with the schema extension into ${basedir}/src/schema. If you opt to store it in another location you must override the maven.eve.schema.dir property in your project.properties file. For each schema file add the file base name to the maven.eve.schemas property which is a comma separated list.

The plugin will by default generate java files within the ${basedir}/target/schema directory. If you would like to generate code elsewhere you must override the maven.eve.schema.target.dir property in your project.properties file.

By default the plugin generates code in an Eve schema package: org.apache.eve.schema.bootstrap. If you want generated code for a schema to be put into a package other than this, then you're going to need to set the package property for the schema. The package property key is composed of the following base, maven.eve.schema.package. with the name of the schema (without the extension) appended to it. So for schema file foo.schema the following property key would be used: maven.eve.schema.package.foo where foo is the schema name.

Using the same pattern above for all schema specific properties you can set other per schema properties as well. One of these properties is the dependency list for a schema. Schemas can obviously depend on others. The schema dependency list is a comma separated list of other schema names. These schemas need not be present in your project to generate the code for your schema. The dependent schema classes must however be present within Eve at deploy time in order to load and use your schema. At the end we list the the default schemas already packaged into the Eve jar. You can use any one of these schemas as dependencies needed by your schema and not worry about their presence. The property key base for the schema dependency list is maven.eve.schema.deps. and for a foo.schema file the full key would be maven.eve.schema.deps.foo

Each schema has an owner associated with it. If you want the owner to be anything other than the Eve super user you may want to set the owner property for the schema in your project.properties file. The property key base for the schema is maven.eve.schema.owner. so don't forget to append the schema name to it.

section.p: The example above is from Eve. If you would like to look at how to use this plugin best the Eve project.properties file here is perhaps the best place to look. Also from the output above you can see the schema files that are used and packaged into Eve by default. This may however change in the future to restrict the set.

WARNING: As a last bit of advice make note that the plugin may be sensitive to case for keywords in the OpenLDAP file. For example the prefix before an objectClass or an attributeType must be in all lowercase. However words like MUST, and MAY and SUP should all be in uppercase. So if plugin bombs just check out where this happens and play with the case. Another thing to watch out for is the order of terms. This we follow the RFC for which is pretty much the same as the OpenLDAP format minus the objectclass and attributetype prefixes to the descriptions. We figure the OpenLDAP parser is less complex if the prefixes are there (where the parser is told if the description is an objectclass or attributetype and does not have to figure this out). However I have encountered schemas whose formats do not comply with standards in with respect to the order of description fields and had to edit the files. This issue did not occur when the files were from the OpenLDAP Foundation which means they do it right but overlook schema objects that are not correctly formated.
